history.content:
It seems you are already really ahead of the game. I'm your fellow rising sophomore international student.

My tips:

1. The most important thing is not about career so far. Spend more time with family since our family is on the other side fo the globe. 

2. Keep yourself sane and a good mental state to be ready for the new start in college!

children.subject:
Wow thank you so much for all the advice! -- they are really helpful & I feel much better about the process now. 

I do have a few clarification questions though!

So recruitment starts in Fall and I'm trying to get an internship for next summer. At the moment, the only classes I've taken that have meaningful projects (imo) are cs61a/cs61b. Like you said, I guess networking comes first, but are the projects from these courses enough to land me internships (or at least interviews)? I probably won't be able to take most (project-oriented and not so mathematical or theoretical) cs upper divs  until next spring. Should I focus on personal projects or taking upper divs first before applying to internsbips?

Another thing--does leetcode help for non-software engineering positions as well? I'm considering swe, but also ML or data. Are there good prep methods for those? Also, I think the upper divs you mentioned are geared towards swe more than other things(?). Do you happen to have recs for upper divs related to ML or data as well?

61B projects and skills are more than enough for you to land a nice internship in the summer. You dont need CS upper divs or anything, the BYOW/gitlet projects are more than enough for you to show your skills. The irony of the CS interviews is that whatever youre being assessed on is 100% the opposite of what youll be doing on the job (which is kinda why I also hate it). You might not get a big tech company from unless you network, but even a small start up is equally, if not, more beneficial for you to learn on the job. Small startups let you work on full scale projects and directly involving you in the codebase/whatever they need to get done whilst big tech companies usually have internship projects lined up for you from the start.

Yeah leetcode also helps for non-swe position I think -- its just a way to practice problem solving with code thats all. Some people need it more than others and thats okay. Other upper divs related to ML/data that is most relevant is 186/ds100. I honestly dont think hard core math (127/189/126) is ever useful on an real ML job at all apart from just you being familiar with the concepts. At the end of the day, you'll be using Pytorch, cvxpy, etc. to do your model training/optimization solving/etc. 

Take a few classes from different areas and figure out what you like. Knowing what you enjoy is arguably more important than taking class X. Personally, I did 127 and learnt a bunch of ML concepts through friends/online only to realize I hate ML and feel like its a scam lol. Some people enjoy it but I probably wont take another ML class here.

wow I'm super late (somehow I missed the notification), but thanks so much again! Are there any other upper divs that you recommend that have some cool projects, other than 186/ds100/161/162 (just in general, not necessarily related to ML)?

Also, I've been hearing a lot that you have to put your apps in by late aug/early sept and otherwise there's a very *low* chance you'll get the job—is this true? And just out of curiosity, did you happen to get an internship after sophomore year? I thought that you kind of need an internship for sophomore year to be able to get the junior internship—do you think this is true in general?

1. Technical interviews can be helped via leetcode as you said. Grinding it out definitely helps. For the behavioral side, you really just need to be honest and answer their questions to the best of your ability. They look for how well you can communicate your ideas and your values as a person. For example, a very common behavioral question is "describe a time you had to work together as a team in a class, what worked/what didnt work and how did you overcome the challenges". Other questions can include like "tell me a time where you got stuck at a bug for a very long time, what did you do?". These are very easy questions if you can simply draw from your experiences and use them as your answers while highlighting who you are as a character/team member. They can prove challenging/detrimental if you answer something like "I never have any codes in my bug" or "I didn't really contribute to my team". 

2. As an international myself, the only "extra things" I did was apply/network more than most other people. In my sophomore year, I applied to about ~300 companies while getting a total of 3 interviews. There are many reasons why this is the case as most medium/smaller companies won't be able to (or they are just really lazy) sponsor your visa for you to work for an internship here, hence why a lot of companies simply reject international students from the get go as they can find someone equally as qualified who is from the States. To REALLY boost your chances, you need to network.

This means going to tech talks by different companies and after the talk, go up to the engineers and have a chat with them, ask them questions about the job, role, and whether there are internship opportunities. If the conversation goes well, you can usually ask them for their contact information. It is on YOU to email them afterwards (even if they said they will contact you) asking them about the job opportunity and what you need to do to move forward. Another way you can network is finding seniors/graduates friends who can give you a referral to the company they are working in. Both these ways bypass the resume screening and rejection and at least give you a chance to get an interview, which honestly is harder than doing well in a technical interview if you are really prepared. I only applied to ~10 companies as a junior this year directly and used 5-6 referrals through friends and got a very good internship this summer. Networking is equally important, if not, more important than leetcoding your way to the top as an international student. You can't show your skills if they dont give you the opportunity to do so.  

3. It doesnt hurt to have personal projects, but its not required. It just provides you another talking point to demonstrate your interest in X and show that you have devoted time/commitment into finishing a long project which could reflect how you'd do at the internship. Personally, I only included big upper division projects I did at Cal without any personal ones and it was fine. They care more about what you did in the project and whether you can explain what you did.  I don't think coursera certificates help at all and projects definitely are more valuable. Don't let your school work suffer because of personal projects though, most of Cal's projects are more than enough to let you shine (162, 186, 161, etc.)

It is beneficial to gear your personal projects to 1 specific direction but really pick something you want to build -- that would lead to a higher rate of success and less chance of you feeling tedious doing something for the sake of doing it vs you doing something you enjoy doing.

The Leetcode 101 DeCal that was offered for the first time last sem aims to help students with these exact worries and prepare them for the recruitment process.

Stay tuned for more info!

I would like to add a bit of info for 2.

Are you by chance a Canadian, Mexican, or Australian citizen? If that's the case, you DO NOT need "sponsorship" post-graduation. You can easily get a TN (Canada and Mexico) or E3 (Australia) work visa and do not need a company to sponsor an H-1B for you to work in the U.S. If this applies to you, let your employers know that you are able to return to their company post-graduation and they will be more lenient when hiring you.

history.content:
I'm an international rising sophomore & I honestly still feel quite clueless about the whole recruitment and interviews etc., but I'm trying to prepare myself for recruitment in fall over the summer & I have a few questions (so I'm sorry if my questions are a lil dumb).

1. how can I prepare for interviews (both behavioral and technical)?

I guess for technical I could grind leetcode, but are there other things you'd recommend I (also) do?

I'm not sure how to get started prepping for the behavioral interviews (I heard upe is useful, but they're closed for the summer)—are there any resources I could look into or tips. 

2. I did hear that the recruitment process is much harder for internationals; are there any extra things I'd need to do during the recruitment process due to my status? If being an international decreases my chances of getting offers, what could I do to increase my chances?

3. In terms of building up resume, I did hear that personal projects help a lot, but do coursera certificates help as well (say for ML)? Are projects and coursera kind of equal in their importance, or do employers still prefer projects more?

Also, while I think I kind of know which direction I want to head in (say software engineering/iOS app dev/ web dev/ ML/data etc), I'm still open to other parts. Should I still gear my personal projects in a single specific direction, or should I try to cover different parts of CS that interest me in my projects?
history.subject: how can I prepare for recruitment/interviews in fall (over the summer)?
